node.accessibility_caption: Photo by dr. helen mo in San Francisco Bay Area. May be an image of text that says 'I know it's hard. I know it can be hard to wake up every day and have these little people rely on you. I know sometimes it's hard to feel like your world is so small. I want to remind you, you are the world. You are the world that your little ones revolve around. You are their nurture, their home, and their comfort. You are to them, and I hope even on your days you know how special you are, especially to these little people. anonymous the.dentistmom'.

node.text:
A little mid week motivation
— because parenting is hard.

How are you feeling this week?
👍🏼 or 👎🏼?

💌: share with a friend who could use some extra love today!

node.text:
LIKE & SAVE FOR LATER ❤️ Let’s talk soft bristle toothbrushes & how to introduce them.

💬: How many teeth does your little one have? What’s your biggest brushing struggle?

⭐️ Read below for my tips!

If your child struggles with brushing, remember that the face is such a personal area and they may need time to find oral healthcare normal. But the more frequent the exposure, the more routine toothbrushing will become.

All children benefit from consistent, and daily exposure when learning new routines.

🦷 BROWSE my Amazon Shop (link in bio) for fun toothbrush options.

______________

⭐️ TEETH ARE IN?
Use a soft bristle toothbrush to adequately remove the plaque and keep the gums healthy.
▫️Pick a toothbrush that makes brushing fun - it could be a favorite character, one that lights up, or one that plays music.
▫️Angle the toothbrush 45 degrees towards the gum, and brush in gentle circles.
▫️Don’t forget to brush all around, including the insides and the tops of the chewing surfaces.

______________

⭐️ INTRODUCING THE TOOTHBRUSH:
STEP-BY-STEP.

1️⃣ EXPLORE & PLAY.
Under supervision, encourage your child’s interest by allowing them to hold the toothbrush & examine at their own pace.

2️⃣ TOUCH & FEEL.
First, don't even brush the teeth. Aim to have your child adapt to the feeling of the spinning.

Start on other body parts, then slowly move up to the area of the face. Start at the outside of the cheek/lips, then the inside of the mouth, and finally rest on top of the teeth or on the gums.

3️⃣ FREQUENT EXPOSURE & DESENSITIZATION.
Every time you brush, set a goal. For example, start with a goal of 1 tooth per brushing, then once that is mastered, increase the goal to 2 teeth, etc. Brush less teeth at a time, but more frequently throughout the day.

Even building your child’s tolerance by a few seconds over the course of weeks is a huge win!

4️⃣ POSITIVE REINFORCEMENT.
Every time you make an improvement, no matter how small, CHEER & make it exciting.

node.text:
LIKE & DROP A ❤️ if brushing is a struggle in your home. Reposting some of my favorite positions for 1 adult.

💬: What are some ways you make brushing fun?

My daughter Olivia (pictured here) is currently 2 yr 4 mos. She used to kick, cry & scream during brushing in a way that was heartbreaking. Even though she hated the physical brushing part, we worked hard to make the “before brushing” & “after brushing” positive. She still has her bad days (totally normal!), but now her behavior has improved so much — with consistent desensitization, daily brushing & some creative twists.
 Brushing may seen like an intimidating task at first, but I promise it will get better. Don’t let the crying or struggles discourage you from making brushing a daily habit. And if you’re struggling, just remember — I’m right there with you!
 ⭐️ Watch my brushing highlights for more tips

_________

BRUSHING TIPS 

1️⃣ Give your child 2 choices.
▫️Which brush — pink or purple?
▫️Which toothpaste — strawberry or mint?

2️⃣ Let your child play with the toothbrush outside of normal brushing.
▫️Your child can like the concept of “brushing”, even if they hate the physical sensation of the toothbrush in their mouth.

Try:
•Roleplaying as a dentist
•Letting them brush your teeth
•Modeling on toys

3️⃣ Make it fun, change it up.
▫️Just like children need “toy rotations” to keep their toys exciting, try different strategies.
▫️The sillier the better!
▫️And as a bonus, making your child laugh means their mouth will OPEN.

4️⃣ Praise & positive reinforcement for desired behaviors.
▫️Be specific — “I love how you kept your mouth open!”

5️⃣ Make it a familiar routine & be consistent.
Much like sleep training, the more established the routine, the less unknown & less scary brushing will become. It’s best to structure brushing within steps of a familiar routine so your child knows what to expect.

6️⃣ Check your body language. Even if it’s hard, try to take a deep breath & stay calm. Your child will feel more confident as well.

❤

Note:
✔️ sharing to IG stories is highly encouraged

❌ please do not take videos of my daughter for your own resale & self promotion

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by dr. helen mo on July 03, 2021 tagging @thisisjules. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'ONE DAY, ALL YOUR CHILDREN WILL HAVE IS A PICTURE OF YOU. MAKE SURE YOU'RE IN THEM. NO MATTER WHAT YOUR HAIR LOOKS LIKE, YOUR MAKE UP OR YOUR BODY, THEY WON'T CARE ABOUT ANY OF THAT, THEY'LL JUST WANT TO SEE YOU.'.

node.text:
📷: @thisisjules. I’m totally guilty of feeling self conscious for pictures. I rarely feel “picture ready.” 

(Anyone else relate?)

But I see it in Olivia’s eyes every time she looks at me:

She loves me without the makeup,
without the fancy touches.

She loves me with the stained sweatpants, yesterday’s t-shirt, and the messy mom bun.

She loves me, despite it all.

🤍🤍🤍

______

Caption from @mother.ly by Cyndy Gatewood 

“Take more pictures of her.

I looked through my phone the other day & realized I have tons of pictures of my husband playing with our kids, but we don't have many of ME with the kids. And it's totally my fault. I'm either always behind the camera, or never want him to take a candid picture of me. I always feel like I have to have on makeup or have a good angle because I have a social media mentality.

But it doesn't have to be that way. We need pictures of our family that include me. I love the pictures of just my kids & I'm so thankful for the pictures I have of my kids & my husband, but it's so important for both of us to be in pictures with them.

Dads, if you have a wife like me, one night when she's laying in bed reading a story to your daughter, whip out your phone and take a picture. When she's in the kitchen talking to your son about his day, take the picture.

Without warning.

Without posing.

Just take the picture.

Time goes by so fast and everyday these sweet babies are getting older and older. Before we know it, they'll be packing up their cars and moving off to college.

Take the picture.

One day she'll be gone & all the kids have left of her are memories.

Take the pictures to show them the love she had for them. Take the pictures so they can always remember how silly she was. Take the pictures so they can see how beautiful she was. It doesn't matter if she's in her pajamas & on day 4 of dry shampoo, please, take the picture.

I know you don't always think about it, but when you do, don't worry about anything else and just take the picture. Your kids (& your wife) will be so grateful in the end.”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by dr. helen mo in California Academy of Sciences with @solidstarts. May be an image of text that says 'Daily Water Intake for Infants & Young Children 6-9 months Optional Less than 4oz (118 mL) day* 2oz 2oz 9-12 months Optional @solidstarts Less than 8oz (227 mL) day* 2oz 2oz 2oz 2oz © 2020 @sol idstarts. All rights reserved 4oz 12-24 months 8oz-32oz (227-946 mL) day 4oz 4oz 4oz 4oz 4oz Minimum intake 4oz 4oz *Unless otherwise directed by your baby's health professional.'.

node.text:
LIKE & SAVE for future reference — thank you Jenny @solidstarts for generously sharing this information with us today.

⭐️ Follow @solidstarts for more information on this topic!

_________________

**Repost from @solidstarts**

Did you know babies don’t have to have water until 12 mos old?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Unless otherwise directed by baby’s health professional, water before age 1 is optional. Breast milk and formula are comprised mostly of water anyway and too much water can displace that valuable nutrition & imbalance an infant’s electrolytes.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Once baby is 6 mos of age, water may be intro’d in small amounts in an open or straw cup as long as baby is growing and gaining appropriately.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
So what is a “small amount”? The AAP suggests offering up to 8 oz (227ml) of water per day starting at 6 mos old; however, it is our strong opinion that water should be limited to less than 2-4 ounces (59-118 ml) a day to avoid displacing valuable nutrition from breast milk or formula (particularly for the youngest babies in this age range). If you’re concerned about hydration, monitor the number of wet diapers and energy levels, and contact your pediatrician.

Generally speaking, babies should have 4-6 good, wet diapers ever 24 hrs.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Believe it or not, water is actually one of the hardest liquids to learn how to drink because it is so thin and flows quickly, which requires the tongue and swallow muscles to work very fast. Do not be worried if your little one coughs when first learning to drink water. The oral motor skills required to drink from a cup or straw are very different than the movements required for breast or bottle feeding! Many times, the liquid is not well contained in the mouth, and a baby coughs & sputters. As baby’s skills improve with cup and straw drinking, this coughing & sputtering should subside with regular practice.

_________________

From a dental perspective, water is one of the healthiest beverages for cavity prevention. It naturally washes away food particles and helps neutralize the mouth after eating.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by dr. helen mo in Exploratorium. May be an image of text that says 'oral sensory-motor DEVELOPMENT the.dentistmom tips wean bottle by 12-18 mos encourage mouthing oral exploration (hands are ok, too!) introduce open cup mos (allow your child time to learn) introduce oral desensitization prior to teeth to increase future brushing success introduce straw cup 6-9 mos, but does not replace open cup drinking ok to start solid food prior to teeth purées & BLW both have their own benefits! try to skip the sippy cups, or wean with similar timing to bottle AAP recommends to start weaning at mos; AAPD recommends full weaning by 2-3 yrs'.

node.text:
LIKE & save for reference!
💬: What stage is your child at?

🤍: follow Catherine @chikidsfeeding for more information on this topic, plus other tips on feeding, speech & general development.

___________

Proper jaw & mouth development is partially dependent on the development of the muscles surrounding the mouth.

GOALS:
▫️Strengthen the jaw: advance the jaw up & down, side to side, and eventually creating circular and diagonal movements.
▫️Lateral tongue movement: helps the jaw shift when the tongue moves side to side, which further strengthens the jaw
▫️Move gag reflex back
▫️Reduce oral hypersensitivity
▫️Proper swallowing pattern: the lips are relaxed to form a “seal,” and the tongue is placed behind the front teeth

___________

WAYS TO PROMOTE ORAL MOTOR-SENSORY DEVELOPMENT.

1️⃣ MOUTHING
Oral exploration is key for oral sensory and motor development. Encourage your child to chew on teething tools using the gums on the sides of the mouth.

2️⃣ BABY LED FEEDING & CHEWING
Not only does this expose your baby to a variety of textures & flavors, it also helps develop dexterity, hand-eye coordination, and oral motor skills. The baby learns chewing, tongue lateralization, and how to move the gag reflex back.

3️⃣ PUREE FEEDING
The wetter food texture teaches your child to move food from the front to the back of the mouth, and allows them to practice lip closure on the spoon.

4️⃣ USING A CUP
You can start introducing an open cup at 6 months. This further helps develop proper oral motor skills.

5️⃣ NEWBORN ORAL CARE
Using a finger brush or silicone toothbrush can stimulate a baby's molar area, inside the cheeks, the tongue, and all around even before the baby has teeth. This will reduce oral hypersensitivity & set your baby up for a higher chance of success for toothbrushing in the future.

⭐️ See my amazon shop for open/straw cup options & our favorite silicone toothbrushes before teeth!

node.text:
Raise your hand 🙋🏻‍♀️ if your baby doesn’t follow the tooth eruption charts.

💬: When was your child’s first tooth? How many teeth do they have now? Share below👇🏼.

Personally, I think tooth eruption charts are a great reference, but I also think they induce unnecessary worry in parents.

Many parents of babies who don’t follow the eruption charts wonder if their child is still “on track” in teeth development. Parents of babies who do follow the tooth eruption charts often lose track of all the confusing numbers on the charts.

So here’s a little trick:

🦷ADD 4 to when the first tooth came in,
🦷 and keep ADDING 4 for 4 teeth 

Does your child follow this?

EXAMPLE: Olivia got her first teeth at 8 months.

So this means:
🤍 4 teeth by 12 (8+4) months
🤍 8 teeth by 16 (12+4) months
🤍 12 teeth by 20 (16+4) months
🤍 16 teeth by 24 (20+4) months
🤍 20 teeth by 28 (24+4) months

_________________________________

HOWEVER, that being said...remember:

🤍 Every child develops at their own pace. This visual is not a rule, only a guide.

🤍 There is a wide range of variability when the first tooth may appear (some even have them when they’re born!) so don’t worry if your child doesn’t follow the norm!

🤍 It can be normal to see teeth late, early, out of order, crooked, with gaps, or straight!

🤍If you’re worried,
✔️consult a dentist if no signs of teeth by 18 mos or the teeth come in 1 year past the expected timing
✔️see a pediatric dentist by age 1 or 6 months after the first tooth erupts

node.text:
Drop a ❤️ if you can relate. How are you doing today — 👍🏼 or 👎🏼?

we can love our children with a love so deep,
with emotions that words will never ever do justice.

& we can also struggle with the job of being “parent.”
with all the overwhelming tasks,
the heavy mental burden.

💌: Tag a parent who could use some support today

node.text:
LIKE & save for later. 💬: What’s your biggest brushing struggle?

Hi 👋🏼 I’m Helen Mo, a pediatric dentist and mom to 2 year old Olivia. Olivia hated brushing when she got her first teeth at 8 mos, but I share our journey to let parents know that even a dentist struggles with teethbrushing.

You are not alone 🤍

🦷: Check out my amazon shop (link in bio) for product recs.

________________________

⭐️ What can I do before teeth are in?
It’s never too early to introduce oral desensitization to prepare your baby for the sensation of brushing before your little one even gets teeth! This builds future brushing tolerance.

⭐️ When can I start brushing?
Once the teeth are in, use a soft bristle toothbrush to adequately remove the plaque and keep the gums healthy.

⭐️ When should I introduce toothpaste?
You can introduce toothpaste once a few teeth erupt, and your little one starts eating solids.

⭐️ What toothpaste should I use?
The current AAPD & AAP guideline is to use a rice or smear sized amount of fluoride toothpaste for kids under 3, and a pea sized amount for kids 3 & up. It is safe if your little one cannot spit, but you can wipe the excess with a washcloth if you’re worried.

⭐️ When should I floss?
Flossing should start when your child has 2 teeth that touch. Often times, this is when the primary molars erupt, around ages 2 to 3. For some kids it may be earlier. Even if your child’s teeth do not touch, it never hurts to introduce the concept early, so by the time you need to floss, your little one will already know what to expect.

⭐️ Should I brush for my baby & toddler?
Yes! You can give your little one some independence by letting them explore (supervised is a must!), but always pair it with a good brushing by an adult.
